subject: Public Speaking
title: The Bandwagon Effect in Speeches
description: One-minute skill: The Bandwagon Effect in Speeches.

hook.text: Millions of people already agree with me. Shouldn't you? The bandwagon effect is social pressure disguised as consensus.

buildup.text: Humans are wired to follow the crowd. When a speaker claims majority support, resistance feels risky and lonely.

discovery.text: The technique works even with fake numbers. Studies show people change views when told 'most people' believe something.

twist.text: The bandwagon effect backfires with contrarians. Some audiences actively resist anything presented as popular.

climax.text: Popularity is not proof. But it feels like proof, and in persuasion, feeling often beats thinking.

punchline.text: Everyone's doing it. That's an argument only if you don't think about it.

quiz.question: What is the bandwagon effect?
options: People adopting views because they believe most others hold them
